text.author: Sophie Arie
text.description: Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi launched a media campaign urging the public to support him as he battles to avoid a corruption conviction by judges he accuses of plotting 'a constitutional coup'. By Sophie Arie.
text.title: Berlusconi launches media counterattack

main.p: The Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, launched a media campaign urging the public to support him as he battles to avoid a corruption conviction by judges he accuses of plotting "a constitutional coup".

The billionaire's possible conviction on bribery charges could come while Italy holds the EU presidency during the second half of this year. Yesterday the newspaper Corriere della Sera published an open letter from Mr Berlusconi, presenting the case for the defence.

Dismissing allegations that in the 1980s he bribed judges to help him take over the giant state food company SME, he called for his trial to be suspended and a parliamentary immunity law to be passed to avert a constitutional crisis.
"We must intervene. And not in order to help the premier 'pass the exam' in the [EU] semester, because I am capable of taking care of that myself," he wrote.
Parliamentary immunity was abolished in 1993, allowing judges in Milan to purge Italy's old political class in the Tangentopoli (Bribesville) trials.

The leftwing opposition sees reviving parliamentary immunity as a step backwards. "Italy is in danger. We risk becoming a regime without even realising it," the centre-left leader Francesco Rutelli told the newspaper La Repubblica.
Mr Berlusconi, who controls three television channels, told listeners to state radio yesterday that the Italian judiciary was using its power to "attack and eliminate" its political enemies.

Many Italians do not see the corruption allegations as a problem and Mr Berlusconi is convinced they would re-elect him. But only 8% of Italians trust their judiciary, he claimed in his letter yesterday.
The prime minister appeared in court on Monday to accuse Romano Prodi, the president of the European commission, of trying to sell off the SME at a cut price in 1985.
Last week Mr Berlusconi's ally Cesare Previti was sentenced to 11 years for bribery.
